threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: Another user impersonates the owner to access the system. They could send false information, or they could use their account with malicious intent.
threats.mitigation:
- Strong password policies
 - Multi-factor authentication (MFA)

data.name: Tag data
data.description: IDs for both the old and the new tag

data.name: Renew data
data.description: Old tag ID, and address to deliver the tag too

data.name: Terminate data
data.description: Email address, tag ID, and dog's name.

threats.title: Unauthorised modification
threats.description: Unauthorized modification of dog records, such as altering the dog's tag ID, registration status, or their owner information.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control, to control who can modify records
 - Automate or perform regular data checks to detect unauthorised changes

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to sensitive dog information, from someone other than the owner. Could also use this information to find out owner-related data
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit who can access information
 - Implement better privacy protocols
 - Don't store any unnecessary sensitive information
 - If sensitive information is necessary, use encryption

threats.title: Overloading the datastore
threats.description: Overloading the datastore with queries or updates. As a result, the datastore could become unavailable or its services could be impacted.
threats.mitigation:
- Implement rate limiting/throttling
 - Monitor and detect unusual behaviour or traffic patterns
 - Ensure that only users with certain roles are able to make such requests

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: An unauthorized person impersonates an actual owner to renew a dog's registration.
threats.mitigation:
- Multi-factor authentication
 - Stronger authentication mechanisms, i.e. use strong passwords, etc
 - Use tokens (or similar) for email or SMS confirmation
 - Don't store any unnecessary private information

threats.title: Attacker alters data
threats.description: An attacker changes the renew request data, such as changing the delivery address, or the tag ID
threats.mitigation:
- Use securer communication channels, such as HTTPS, to ensure that data is transmitted safely and discretely
 - Implement hashing or digital signatures to check the integrity of data
 - Validate all incoming data to ensure it hasn't been tampered with

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to sensitive information during the renewal process, such as the owner's personal details or the dog's information
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to sensitive data
 - Encrypt data throughout the process to prevent unauthorized access
 - Implement data masking, so sensitive information is hidden where necessary
 - Don't use/provide unnecessary sensitive information throughout

threats.title: System flooding
threats.description: An attacker floods the system with renewal requests, likely leading to the service going down.
threats.mitigation:
- Limit the number of termination requests allowed per user or IP address in a given time frame
 - Monitor for unusual behaviour or traffic and implement automatic blocking or throttling mechanisms to help
 - Use load balancers to distribute traffic and handle spikes in requests

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains elevated privileges and can renew any registration, no matter their authorization level.
threats.mitigation:
- Implement the principle of least privilege. Ensure that users and systems have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their functions
 - Conduct regular security audits to identify and fix any vulnerabilities that could allow this
 - Ensure access control methods are secure

threats.title: Unauthorised modification
threats.description: Unauthorized modification of owner records, such as email addresses, home addresses, related dogs, etc.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control, to control who can modify records
 - Automate or perform regular data checks to detect unauthorised changes
 - Use input validation

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to sensitive owner information, including personal details (email address, home address), billing data, etc.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit who can access information
 - Implement better privacy protocols
 - Don't store any unnecessary sensitive information
 - If sensitive information is necessary, use encryption

threats.title: Overloading the datastore
threats.description: Overloading the datastore with queries or updates. As a result, the datastore could become unavailable, or its services could be impacted.
threats.mitigation:
- Implement rate limiting/throttling
 - Monitor and detect unusual behaviour or traffic patterns
 - Ensure that only users with certain roles are able to make such requests

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: An attacker impersonates the invoice process to issue or alter invoices
threats.mitigation:
- Inform users of this possibility, and how to detect false invoices
 - Use technologies to authenticate legitimate invoices
 - Use strong authentication for access to the invoice system
 - Use digital signatures

threats.title: Attacker alters data
threats.description: An attacker alters the invoice details, such as amounts, recipient information, details on how to pay, etc.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to who can view or modify invoices
 - Use secure protocols to ensure the invoices can’t be tampered with in transit
 -  Inform users of this possibility, and how to detect false invoices
 - Use digital signatures

threats.title: Repudiation threat
threats.description: A user denies receiving an invoice, or claims to have payed when they hadn’t. Or an invoice was incorrectly sent to the wrong recipient, or an invoice was incorrect (I.e. amount, details, etc)
threats.mitigation:
- Maintain logs of all invoice actions
 - Use digital signatures or electronic receipts
 - Request replies or read receipts for important information

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to invoice details, such as amounts or owner information.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to sensitive data
 - Don't use/provide unnecessary sensitive information throughout 
 - Anonymise information where possible to help reduce the impacts if leaked
 - Store sensitive invoices securely
 - Encrypt sensitive invoice information when possible

threats.title: System flooding
threats.description: An attacker disrupts the invoicing system, impacting the creation or sending of invoices
threats.mitigation:
- Control the rate of invoices created and sent
 - Identify an incident response for these cases
 - Monitor the system for any unusual behaviour

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains access to manage/change the invoicing system
threats.mitigation:
- Implement the principle of least privilege. Ensure that users and systems have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their functions
 - Conduct regular security audits to identify and fix any vulnerabilities that could allow this
 - Use strong passwords or MFA

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: An attacker impersonates the council delivery service and redirects/steals packages
threats.mitigation:
- Use secure authentication methods for delivery service access
 - Ensure secure communication between the delivery service, the owner, and the council. Better yet, ensure these methods are encrypted and require authentication.

threats.title: Attacker alters data
threats.description: An attacker modifies the delivery address, the delivery schedule, or the tracking information
threats.mitigation:
- Use secure communication channels, such as HTTPS, to ensure that data is transmitted safely and discretely
 - Implement hashing or digital signatures to check the integrity of data
 - Validate all incoming data to ensure it hasn't been tampered with
 - Restrict access to delivery data to authorised personnel only

threats.title: Repudiation threat
threats.description: The delivery service claims they never received a tag to be delivered, or claimed they delivered a package when they didn’t, or delivers a package to the wrong address.
threats.mitigation:
- Implement a tracking system with logging of delivery details and timestamps
 - Get owners to sign for their delivery/tag

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to sensitive information, such as the owners address
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to sensitive data
 - Encrypt data throughout the process to prevent unauthorised access
 - Implement data masking, so sensitive information is hidden where necessary
 - Don't use/provide unnecessary sensitive information throughout 
 - Anonymise information where possible to help reduce the impacts if leaked

threats.title: System flooding
threats.description: An attacker disrupts the delivery service, causing delays or failures
threats.mitigation:
- Identify an incident response for these cases
 - Have backups available in-case this happens

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains elevated privileges to manage/change the delivery system
threats.mitigation:
- Implement the principle of least privilege. Ensure that users and systems have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their functions
 - Conduct regular security audits to identify and fix any vulnerabilities that could allow this
 - Ensure access control methods are secure

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: An unauthorized person impersonates an actual owner to terminate a dog's registration.
threats.mitigation:
- Multi-factor authentication
 - Stronger authentication mechanisms, i.e. use strong passwords, etc
 - Use tokens (or similar) for email or SMS confirmation
 - Don't store any unnecessary private information

threats.title: Attacker alters data
threats.description: An attacker changes the termination request data, such as changing the email address, dog information, or registration status.
threats.mitigation:
- Use securer communication channels, such as HTTPS, to ensure that data is transmitted safely and discretely
 - Implement hashing or digital signatures to check the integrity of data
 - Validate all incoming data to ensure it hasn't been tampered with

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to sensitive information during the termination process, such as the owner's personal details or the dog's information.
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to sensitive data
 - Encrypt data throughout the process to prevent unauthorized access
 - Implement data masking, so sensitive information is hidden where necessary
 - Don't use/ask for unnecessary sensitive information throughout

threats.title: System flooding
threats.description: An attacker floods the system with termination requests, likely leading to the service going down.
threats.mitigation:
- Limit the number of termination requests allowed per user or IP address in a given time frame
 - Monitor for unusual behaviour or traffic and implement automatic blocking or throttling mechanisms to help
 - Use load balancers to distribute traffic and handle spikes in requests

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains elevated privileges and can terminate any registration, no matter their authorization level.
threats.mitigation:
- Implement the principle of least privilege. Ensure that users and systems have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their functions
 - Conduct regular security audits to identify and fix any vulnerabilities that could allow this
 - Ensure access control methods are secure

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: An attacker sends fraudulent emails pretending to be from the council or the registration system
threats.mitigation:
- Inform users of this possibility, and how to detect phishing emails
 - Use technologies to authenticate legitimate emails

threats.title: Attacker alters data
threats.description: An attacker alters the content of actual real emails in transit
threats.mitigation:
- Use secure protocols to ensure the emails can’t be tampered with in transit
 - Use digital signatures

threats.title: Repudiation threat
threats.description: A user denies receiving an email, or disputes the content. Or the email system claims to have sent an email when they hadn’t, or fails to admit they sent an email to the wrong address.
threats.mitigation:
- Maintain logs of all email communications
 - Use digital signatures
 - Request replies or read receipts for important information

threats.title: Unauthorised access
threats.description: Unauthorised access to email content or attachments (such as tag, dog, or owner information)
threats.mitigation:
- Use role-based access control to limit access to sensitive data
 - Don't use/provide unnecessary sensitive information throughout 
 - Anonymise information where possible to help reduce the impacts if leaked
 - Store sensitive emails and attachments securely

threats.title: System flooding
threats.description: An attacker floods the email system with large volumes of emails, disrupting the email service
threats.mitigation:
- Implement spam filtering solutions
 - Identify an incident response for these cases
 - Limit the number of email sending and recieving
 - Monitor for unusual behaviour or traffic and implement automatic blocking or throttling mechanisms to help

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains access to manage/change the email system
threats.mitigation:
- Implement the principle of least privilege. Ensure that users and systems have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their functions
 - Conduct regular security audits to identify and fix any vulnerabilities that could allow this
 - Use strong passwords or MFA

threats.title: Impersonating a dog owner
threats.description: Actor can enter an email address that is not theirs.
threats.mitigation: Request two-factor authentication before being able to report a lost dog.

threats.title: Repudiation of lost dog report
threats.description:
A dog owner (or someone impersonating as a dog owner) may 
- say they never reported their dog lost and the system says the dog has a lost status
- or say they have reported their dog and the system says the dog is not lost
threats.mitigation: - Logging all changes to a dog status with timestamps

data.name: Dog tag ID and lost status

labels: Dog tag ID and lost status

data.name: Dog tag ID and lost status

labels: Dog tag ID and lost status

threats.title: Using another user's credentials
threats.description:
Using another user's credentials to register a dog as another user.
Potentially due to a user having weak credentials being stolen
threats.mitigation: Send confirmation emails or letters to ensure that users are who they claim to be

threats.title: Claiming no registration
threats.description: After registering a dog and receiving the tag, users could claim that they did not register the dog and refuse to pay the invoice
threats.mitigation: Store a record of users interactions with the system

threats.title: Altering Registration Data
threats.description: Man in the middle attacks could alter user registration details
threats.mitigation:
- Use securer communication channels, such as HTTPS, to ensure that data is transmitted safely and discretely
 - Implement hashing or digital signatures to check the integrity of data
 - Validate all incoming data to ensure it hasn't been tampered with

threats.title: Gaining Admin Access
threats.description: Attacker gains developer or administrator access to the system, allowing them to access or edit parts of the system they should not be able to
threats.mitigation:
Enact the least privilege principle
Ensure that each level of privilege is secure

threats.title: Impersonation
threats.description: User impersonates someone to register a dog with details that do not belong to them.
threats.mitigation:
Send confirmation emails
Use MFA

threats.title: Unauthorised access to user information
threats.description: Third parties steal personal user data such as name, address, and email
threats.mitigation:
Store as little personal data as required
Encrypt personal data
Ensure limited access to user data

threats.title: Request flooding
threats.description: Malicious third parties sending many registration requests in a short amount of time in an attempt to overload the server
threats.mitigation:
- Limit the number of registration requests allowed per user or IP address in a given time frame
 - Monitor for unusual behaviour or traffic and implement automatic blocking or throttling mechanisms to help
 - Use load balancers to distribute traffic and handle spikes in requests

threats.title: Unauthorised modification
threats.description: Editing user or dog data without permission
threats.mitigation: Only allow people with Admin permissions to edit data

threats.title: Data leaks
threats.description: Third parties getting access to data they should not have access
threats.mitigation:
Ensure extra permissions to access user data
Store bare minimum data 
Encrypt sensitive data

threats.title: Overloading system
threats.description: Sending a large number of database access/manipulation requests in a short time in order to overload the server and affect intended functionality
threats.mitigation:
Add rate limiting
Ensure only a certain number of requests per IP address per unit time

threats.title: Compromised Admin Edits not Traceable
threats.description: A compromised admin account makes edits to data but which account is compromised is unidentifiable
threats.mitigation: Log database operations with the account that made the operation

threats.title: Impersonate Users to Steal Tag Packages
threats.description: Using data that does not belong to them, a third party has packages sent to their own address instead of that of the intended recipient
threats.mitigation:
- Use secure authentication methods for delivery service access
 - Ensure secure communication between the delivery service, the owner, and the council. Better yet, ensure these methods are encrypted and require authentication.

threats.title: Attacker Edits Delivery Data
threats.description: An attacker modifies the delivery address, the delivery schedule, or the tracking information
threats.mitigation:
- Use secure communication channels, such as HTTPS, to ensure that data is transmitted safely and discretely
 - Implement hashing or digital signatures to check the integrity of data
 - Validate all incoming data to ensure it hasn't been tampered with
 - Restrict access to delivery data to authorised personnel only

data.name: Member of public
data.description: A member of the public is a person not necessarily associated with the application who finds a lost dog

threats.title: Report found dog pretending to be someone else
threats.description: A report of a found dog comes from a malicious actor (not a genuine report)
threats.mitigation:
Require photographic proof of the lost dog and its associated ID number when reporting a found dog.
Use HTTPS-only and secure cookies.

threats.title: Deny having reported found dog
threats.description: Member of public claims that they did not report a found dog.
threats.mitigation:
Trace (log) session id, timestamp, originating IP.
Require photographic proof of the lost dog and its associated ID number when reporting a found dog - so there is a trace of the reported dog.

threats.title: Malicious actor pretends to be dog services
threats.description: Malicious actor pretends to be dog services in order to pick up lost dogs.
threats.mitigation:
Provide anticipated identification (and timeframe) for the dog services coming to pick up the dog.
Ensure that the dog services have been vetted as legitimate (on the application's behalf)

threats.title: Dog services pretends to not recieve dog location
threats.description: Dog services pretends to not have recieved lost dog location for pickup, or pretends that they have not picked up the dog.
threats.mitigation: Have a trace of actions (member of public marks dog as picked up).

threats.title: Dog owner registered with invalid details
threats.description: A dog owner is registered with invalid/incorrect details (such as email address).
threats.mitigation:
Require email address validation when registering.
Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature (to ensure actor is human).

threats.title: Dog ower uses another's details
threats.description: A dog owner uses another person's email address, or uses another person's dog details.
threats.mitigation: Require email validation when registering.

threats.title: Report a fake dog
threats.description: A dog that does not exist is reported as found
threats.mitigation:
Require proof of found dog, and its associated ID.
Use HTTP-only and secure cookies.

threats.title: Adversary in the middle change content of dog report
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the dog report and modifies its content.
threats.mitigation:
Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id.
Sign (hash) content with user's private key.

threats.title: Deny having reported dog
threats.description: Member of public claims they have not reported a lost dog.
threats.mitigation:
Log traces of found dog reports.
Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature (to ensure human users)

threats.title: Stolen details
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the personal data of the member of the public, or the dog (such as the dog's ID, or the public member's physical address)
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooding of found dog reports
threats.description: Many reports of a found dog per second (coming from the same IP.)
threats.mitigation:
Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature.
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls).

threats.title: Gaining elevated access by dog report
threats.description: An adversary attempts to elevate their privilege in the system via a found dog report.
threats.mitigation:
Sanitise inputs to prevent an injection attack.
Ensure access follows the 'least privilege' principle, and have integrity/access control.
Regularly monitor and maintain access logs for DB.

data.name: Lookup dog details
data.description: Search for dog details and owner details based on given dog ID

threats.title: Adversary in the middle attack
threats.description: A man-in-the-middle could modify dog (and owner) details as the request is placed.
threats.mitigation:
Use secured connection protocol.
Ensure IP is consistent for the whole process.

threats.title: Flooding of requests from same IP
threats.description: Many dog owner detail requests per second coming from the same IP.
threats.mitigation:
Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls)

threats.title: Details stolen
threats.description: Details about a dog (and its owner) are stolen as the request is placed - adversary in the middle.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Fake user in the system
threats.description: An unauthorized person pretends to be a vaild user of the system in order to gain access to personal information about dogs and dog owners.
threats.mitigation:
Implement MFA, and requirements for strong passwords. 
Only store information that is needed.

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges
threats.description: An attacker gains elevated privileges and can access the database, no matter their authorization level.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure access follows the 'least privilege' principle, and have integrity/access control.
Regularly monitor and maintain access logs for DB

threats.title: Lack of logs
threats.description: An adversary removes or modified logs to hide malicious access to personal data.
threats.mitigation:
Require MFA, and strong password requirements.
Encrypt and/or sign logs to prevent tampering.
Monitor and maintain logs regularly.

threats.title: Malicious actor pretending to be council
threats.description: Malicious actor pretends to be council and contact dog owner to get more information about them/their dog.
threats.mitigation: Recommed that users take measures to learn to recognise phising emails, and to implement email filtering to flag suspicious emails.

threats.title: Insecure connection
threats.description: Email to dog owner is caught in transit and modified - this could be to change the dog pickup location, or the fact that the dog was found at all.
threats.mitigation: Use S/MIME so that the reciever can ensure the email has not been modified.

threats.title: Dog owner denies having recieved email
threats.description: Dog owner denies having recieved email regarding their found dog
threats.mitigation:
Keep logs for emails, and confirmation that an email was sent
Request read reciepts for important communication.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog or their owner (like their physical/email address or dog ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Email DDoS
threats.description: A malicious actor tries to overwhelm an email server.
threats.mitigation: Implement a load balancer, and block communication from outdated or unused ports, protocols, and applications.

threats.title: Attacker gains elevated privileges in the system
threats.description: Attacker gains elevated privileges in the system, and can contact dog owners about a found dog in a misleading (modified data) or incorrect (fake data) manner
threats.mitigation:
Ensure access follows the 'least privilege' principle, and have integrity/access control.
Regularly monitor and maintain access logs for DB.

threats.title: Adversary in the middle change dog details
threats.description: An adversary-in-the-middle intercepts the dog detail lookup to modify the dog's or associated owner's details.
threats.mitigation:
Use secure connection, http-only and secure cookie with unique session id.
Sign (hash) content with user's private key.

threats.title: Dog data stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data related to a dog and its owner.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Many reports of a lost dog
threats.description: Many reports of a lost dog in an attempt to flood the system.
threats.mitigation: Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature.

threats.title: Insecure connection
threats.description: Data can be tampered by an adversary in the middle where the address for the found dog or its ID can be modified.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security for the communication.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the personal data of the member of public (like their address).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooding of requests from same IP
threats.description: Many found dog reports per second coming from the same IP.
threats.mitigation:
Enable a CAPTCHA-like feature
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls)

threats.title: Modified ack
threats.description: Adversary in the middle captures acknowledgement of found dog report, so member of public unsure if report was recieved.
threats.mitigation: Use secure connection.

threats.title: Details disclosed
threats.description: Information associated to the found dog report is captured in transit - depending on what information is part of the report ack, this may not be a large problem.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: End user flooded with ack
threats.description: End user is flooded with found dog report acks.
threats.mitigation: Recommend to user that they implement an IDS/Firewall to filter network traffic

threats.title: Insecure connection
threats.description: Data can be tampered by an adversary in the middle where the address for the found dog or its ID can be modified.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog (like their current physical address or ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooding reports to dog services
threats.description: Reports of a dog to pickup are flooded to the dog services.
threats.mitigation: Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter GPS coordinates updates (network traffic)

threats.title: Modified ack
threats.description: Adversary in the middle captures acknowledgement, so it is unclear if the dog services have/will pick up the dog.
threats.mitigation: Use secure connection.

threats.title: Details disclosed
threats.description: Information associated with the dog is captured in transit - depending on what information is part of the report ack, this may not be a large problem (could be physical or email address)
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooding dog pickup confirmations
threats.description: Adversary floods system with confirmations of a dog pickup.
threats.mitigation: Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter network traffic

threats.title: Dog details modified
threats.description: Adversary in the middle modifies the dog details in transit (such as current address, or dog ID), so the incorrect dog is picked up, or the reported dog is not.
threats.mitigation:
Use secured connection protocol.
Sign (hash) content with private key to know that information has not been modified.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog (like their current physical address or ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooded requests
threats.description: Packets are flooded in the network.
threats.mitigation:
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.
Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter GPS coordinates updates (network traffic).

threats.title: Details modified
threats.description: The ID of the requested dog is modified by an adversary in the middle, so that the wrong dog's details are looked for and returned.
threats.mitigation:
Use secured connection protocol.
Ensure IP is consistent for the whole process.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog or their owner.
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooded requests
threats.description: Flooded requests for database information.
threats.mitigation:
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.
Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter GPS coordinates updates (network traffic).
Implement integrity controls on the database to only allow certain users access.

threats.title: Dog details modified
threats.description: Adversary in the middle modifies the dog details in transit (such as current address, or dog ID), so the incorrect dog is picked up, or the reported dog is not.
threats.mitigation:
Use secured connection protocol.
Sign (hash) content with private key to know that information has not been modified.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog or their owner (like their physical/email address or dog ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooded requests
threats.description: Packets are flooded in the network.
threats.mitigation:
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.
Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter GPS coordinates updates (network traffic).

threats.title: Dog details modified
threats.description: Adversary in the middle modifies the dog details in transit (such as current address, or dog ID), so the incorrect dog is picked up, or the reported dog is not.
threats.mitigation:
Use secured connection protocol.
Sign (hash) content with private key to know that information has not been modified.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog or their owner (like their physical/email address or dog ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooded requests
threats.description: Packets (database responses) are flooded in the network.
threats.mitigation:
Disallow multiple requests from same origin IP (IP blocking after multiple calls) within in few seconds.
Implement an IDS/Firewall to filter GPS coordinates updates (network traffic).

threats.title: Dog details modified
threats.description: The email to the found dog owner is modified in transit so the owner is not properly notified that their dog has been found, and they don't know that they can pick it up.
threats.mitigation: Use S/MIME so that the reciever can ensure the email has not been modified.

threats.title: Personal data can be stolen
threats.description: An adversary in the middle can steal the data associated with a found dog or their owner (like their physical/email address or dog ID).
threats.mitigation: Use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for the communication.

threats.title: Flooded emails
threats.description: Dog owner flooded with emails of found dog information.
threats.mitigation: Recommend end-user implement email filtering and/or a firewall for packet filtering.
